Award.AwardTitle: Problems in Higher Dimensional Algebraic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
As a link between algebra and geometry, the main goal of algebraic geometry is to understand geometrically certain objects called algebraic varieties (i.e., common zero sets of multivariable polynomials). These very natural and fundamental algebraic objects appear frequently in many branches of mathematics and science. Hence, algebraic geometry sees many applications in other parts of mathematics such as number theory or complex geometry, and also in other scientific or engineering disciplines such as physics, coding theory, robotics, and computational biology. In particular, any general structure theory of these algebraic objects can be very useful in many fields of study. The part of algebraic geometry devoted to this structure theory is called higher dimensional algebraic geometry and it is the main subject of this research project. The project aims to further develop the theory of higher dimensional algebraic geometry.

For studying varieties over a field of characteristic zero and of positive characteristic, there are very different tools available. Examples of the former are Hodge theory and the related vanishing theorems, while examples for the latter are Frobenius lifting techniques or quotients by p-closed foliations. In particular, the above dichotomy yields two remarkably different cases to most conjectures of higher dimensional algebraic geometry. The particular flavor of this project is that it concerns standard topics and conjectures of higher dimensional algebraic geometry both in characteristic zero and in positive characteristic, such as higher dimensional moduli spaces, minimal model program, subadditivity of Kodaira dimension, and Shafarevich type hyperbolicity conjectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A central aim of science is to search for hidden patterns that can reveal important properties. In mathematics this frequently means looking for hidden patterns in large data sets or other objects.  For example, if a large collection of numbers all end in the digit 3, we strongly suspect that this has a reason. We think of it as all these numbers have residue 3 when divided by 10. It turns out to be especially fruitful to look similarly at residues when we divide not by 10 but by various prime numbers.

Frequently the patterns are more complicated, and we see polynomial relations among various residues. Roughly speaking, algebraic geometry in characteristic p is the search for polynomial patterns when we compute residues when dividing by a prime number p.  The key in these investigations is to study systems of polynomial equations.  The aim of the project was to develop a theoretical framework which describes the possibly  polynomial relations for residues when dividing by a prime number p. The simplest case is when we have one free parameter, this is the study of algebraic curves. The project looked at the next case when we have two free parameters, these are algebraic surfaces. The main outcome is that  algebraic surfaces naturally come in families and these families themselves can be described by polynomial equations.

In some cases these equations have been worked out completely, but a lot more work needs to be done to understand more cases and to develop a clear description in general.
